author: jiekai9348
content: <@!624875260373762069> sorry, I did't hear it clearly at the meeting.  You are working on removing the 2300 gas stipend right? You were saying setting it to 0 may cause problems?

author: uink45
content: <@!521886109870063627>, apologies for the audio issues. The goal of my project would be to explore the impact of removing the gas stipend (2300). What I have found out so far is that, in the case where `CallStipend` is set to 0, it breaks transactions that were initiated using `.send()` and `.transfer()`. I will be doing deeper analysis on this topic and document it in the next development update.

author: nasdf
content: <@!364458974906548225> I'm definitely interested in the idea of an SSZ codec for IPLD.  Here's a link to the docs for anyone that's interested: https://ipld.io/docs/

author: pipermerriam
content: open'd this as a stub issue: https://github.com/ethereum-cdap/cohort-one/issues/60

author: _jmc_.
content: Just out of curiosity, whatever happened to swarm? Was it developed sufficiently to be a candidate data layer for the portal network?

author: pipermerriam
content:
I did a lot of research into use of general purpose storage networks for stuff like this and back when I did, I ran into the same problem in swarm and IPFS.  The content address they use is not the same content address we use.  For example, the block hash, which is the content address we have available for block headers, is `keccak(rlp(header))` but swarm uses it's own scheme for hashing objects into a content address.  So there was no clear way to use their network for since we don't have the right kind of hash to reference the content within their network.

IPLD seems to solve this by allowing for not only custom hashing schemes to arrive at a content address but also custom ways to structure the data so that you can do more complex addressing schemes that end up being necessary if you want to do things efficiently such as storing merkle trie data.

And then the 3rd part is, that you have to actually have access to the data.  In my case, I was looking for ways to be "lightweight" but to get access to swarm in a Peer-2-Peer manner, you had to basically implement the full SWARM/IPFS protocol or have some sort of light version of those protocols that you can implement.
